s.text: The all-survivors group using the last observation carried forward analysis totaled 897 patients, whereas the in-hospital group totaled 118.

The all-survivors group using the last observation carried forward analysis totaled 897 patients, whereas the in-hospital group totaled 118.
In the SAPS II system, a score-to-risk transformation developed by Le Gall et al . [ 16] for sepsis patients was used.
The all-survivors group using the last observation carried forward analysis totaled 897 patients, whereas the in-hospital group totaled 118.
In cases in which there was no patient response at 90 days because they had been discharged, the data from the last assessment but before 90 days were used.
Unfortunately, patients hospitalized with severe sepsis may be unable to complete a QoL measure or it may be too burdensome.

The results of the study indicate that, over a 90-day period, survivors of severe sepsis receiving AT III experienced substantial and statistically significant improvements as compared with placebo in several attributes of QoL.
QoL gives information on what medical care has achieved for the patient, but severe sepsis is a difficult area in which to obtain such information.
Unfortunately, patients hospitalized with severe sepsis may be unable to complete a QoL measure or it may be too burdensome.
Future studies of critically ill patients with severe sepsis or other conditions should include long-term follow up of patients throughout hospitalization and after hospital discharge.
Unfortunately, patients hospitalized with severe sepsis may be unable to complete a QoL measure or it may be too burdensome.
The purpose of this investigation was to establish whether these trends also held for the subjective effects of AT III in severe sepsis.
In treating patients with severe sepsis, physicians are mainly concerned with biologic, physiologic, and clinical outcomes.
Unfortunately, patients hospitalized with severe sepsis may be unable to complete a QoL measure or it may be too burdensome.
